prompt.system_instruction: You are an AI Assistant, tasked with providing responses that are well-grounded in the provided documents. Given one or more documents and a user query, generate a response to the query. If no answer can be found in the documents, say, "I do not have specific information".

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: How old do I have to be to drive in CA?

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: To get a provisional instruction permit or the “learner’s permit", you must be at least 15 ½ years old. However, I do not have information on the minimum age requirements for a driver's license in California.

contexts.text:
Instruction and Learner's Permits - California DMV

AB 60 Driver’s Licenses

Knowledge and Drive Tests Preparation

The first milestone on the road to getting your California driver’s license (DL) is to obtain your provisional instruction permit, sometimes called a “learner’s permit.” This is for people who are learning to drive and working on the requirements to get a DL.

Visit the California Driver’s Handbook to get all the knowledge you need to start!

info-icon

	Notification icon	

Help improve the way California drivers get a license. Download the new mobile DMV TestBuddy App!

	To apply for a California Instruction Permit (under age 18), you must:
	

plus

minus

Be at least 15 ½ but under 18.
Have a Certificate of Completion/Enrollment of Driver Education.
Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application.
Have a parent(s)/guardian(s) sign the application.
Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), where you will:

Bring your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency. (Federal Noncompliant/REAL ID/AB60)
Pay the application fee.
Pass a vision exam.
Take a photo.
Take the knowledge test(s). There are multiple choice questions based on the California Driver’s Handbook, and a passing score is 80%.

Please refer to Provisional Licensing for additional information.

	To apply for a California Instruction Permit (over age 18), you must:
	

plus

minus

	To apply for a California Instruction Permit (over age 18), you must:
	

plus

minus

Be at least 18.
Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application.
Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), where you will:

Bring your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency. (Federal Noncompliant/REAL ID/AB60)
Pay the application fee.
Pass a vision exam.
Take a photo.
Take the knowledge test(s). There are multiple choice questions based on the California Driver’s Handbook, and a passing score is 80%.

Please refer to Driver’s Licenses for additional information.

	To apply for a California Motorcycle Instruction Permit, you must:
	

plus

minus

Be at least 15 ½.
Have a Certificate of Completion of Driver Education and Driver Training if you are between the ages of 15 ½ and 17 ½.
Complete a California Highway Patrol approved California Motorcyclist Safety Program (CMSP) motorcyclist training course, and receive a Certificate of Completion of Motorcycle Training (DL 389) if you are between the ages of 15 ½ to 21.
Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application.
Have a parent(s)/guardian(s) sign the application if you are under 18.
Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), where you will:

Bring your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency. (Federal Noncompliant/REAL ID/AB60)
Pay the application fee.
Pass a vision exam.
Take a photo.
Take the knowledge test(s). There are multiple choice questions based on the California Motorcycle Handbook, and a passing score is 80%.

Please refer to Motorcycle Licenses for additional information.
contexts.title: Instruction and Learner's Permits - California DMV

ml.tokens.model_text: |user|: How old do I have to be to drive in CA?

contexts.text:
Instruction and Learner's Permits - California DMV
If you fail both attempts, you will need to go to a DMV office to take the test a third time.
What is Financial Responsibility (Insurance)?
Proof of financial responsibility must be always carried in the vehicle. Most Californians maintain financial responsibility through insurance companies, which provide the policy holder with an identification card to be used as proof of coverage. The card must state the insurance company’s name and address, the period of coverage, and policy number.
Financial responsibility in California requires that drivers and vehicle owners carry the following minimum dollar limits:

$15,000 for injury or death of 1 person per accident.
$30,000 for injury or death of 2 or more persons per accident.
$5,000 for any property damage per accident.

When parents or guardians sign for a minor to get a DL, they are stating that they will accept financial responsibility for that minor.
I’m almost 18. Do I need to take driver education/driver training (DE/DT) in order to get my instruction permit?
If you are over 17 ½ but under 18 years of age, you may get your instruction permit without the DE/DT certificates. However, you will not be able to take the driving test until you are 18 years of age.
What do I do if I completed my DE/DT in another state? (Applies to applicants under 18 years of age) 
If your DE/DT were completed in a state other than California, DMV will accept a letter from your out-of-state secondary school on the school’s official stationery. The letter must be signed by a school official stating that the completed courses you have taken are equivalent to a California secondary school course as described in Section 10020 of Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations and on form “To Secondary Schools Other Than California Schools” (DL 33). Obtain a DL 33 form from your local DMV office or by calling DMV at 1-800-777-0133. Send the DL 33 form to your out-of-state school for completion. An out-of-state driving instruction permit is not acceptable proof of DE/DT.
What if my provisional instruction permit expires before I take the driving test?
contexts.title: Instruction and Learner's Permits - California DMV

messages.original_text: In California, you must be at least 16 years old to drive with a learner's permit and at least 18 years old to drive without supervision.

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: Are you sure? I am pretty sure you can get a permit as soon as you are 15 years old.

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: Based on my information, the minimum age to get a provisional instruction permit in California is 15 ½ years.

messages.original_text:
To apply for a California Instruction Permit, you must be at least 15 ½ years old (under 18) or 18 years old (for adults). Here are the steps to follow:
For applicants under 18 years old:
1. Obtain a Certificate of Completion/Enrollment of Driver Education.
2. Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application.
3. Have a parent(s)/guardian(s) sign the application.
4. Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), bringing your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency, paying the application fee, passing a vision exam, taking a photo, and taking the knowledge test(s).
For applicants 18 years old or older:
1. Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application.
2. Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), bringing your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency, paying the application fee, passing a vision exam, taking a photo, and taking the knowledge test(s).
For a California Motorcycle Instruction Permit, the steps are similar, but you must also have a Certificate of Completion of Driver Education and Driver Training (if you are between 15 ½ and 17 ½) or complete a California Highway Patrol approved California Motorcyclist Safety Program (CMSP) motorcyclist training course (if you are between 15 ½ and 21).

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: If you are under age 18, to apply for a California Instruction Permit, you must: - Be at least 15 ½ but under 18. - Have a Certificate of Completion/Enrollment of Driver Education. - Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application. - Have a parent(s)/guardian(s) sign the application. - Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), where you will:  - Bring your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency. (Federal Noncompliant/REAL ID/AB60)  - Pay the application fee.  - Pass a vision exam.  - Take a photo.  - Take the knowledge test(s). There are multiple choice questions based on the California Driver’s Handbook, and a passing score is 80%. If you are over the age of 18, the steps differ. Please let me know if you want more details about that process.

contexts.text:
Instruction and Learner's Permits - California DMV
If you fail both attempts, you will need to go to a DMV office to take the test a third time.
What is Financial Responsibility (Insurance)?
Proof of financial responsibility must be always carried in the vehicle. Most Californians maintain financial responsibility through insurance companies, which provide the policy holder with an identification card to be used as proof of coverage. The card must state the insurance company’s name and address, the period of coverage, and policy number.
Financial responsibility in California requires that drivers and vehicle owners carry the following minimum dollar limits:

$15,000 for injury or death of 1 person per accident.
$30,000 for injury or death of 2 or more persons per accident.
$5,000 for any property damage per accident.

When parents or guardians sign for a minor to get a DL, they are stating that they will accept financial responsibility for that minor.
I’m almost 18. Do I need to take driver education/driver training (DE/DT) in order to get my instruction permit?
If you are over 17 ½ but under 18 years of age, you may get your instruction permit without the DE/DT certificates. However, you will not be able to take the driving test until you are 18 years of age.
What do I do if I completed my DE/DT in another state? (Applies to applicants under 18 years of age) 
If your DE/DT were completed in a state other than California, DMV will accept a letter from your out-of-state secondary school on the school’s official stationery. The letter must be signed by a school official stating that the completed courses you have taken are equivalent to a California secondary school course as described in Section 10020 of Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations and on form “To Secondary Schools Other Than California Schools” (DL 33). Obtain a DL 33 form from your local DMV office or by calling DMV at 1-800-777-0133. Send the DL 33 form to your out-of-state school for completion. An out-of-state driving instruction permit is not acceptable proof of DE/DT.
What if my provisional instruction permit expires before I take the driving test?

messages.original_text:
To apply for a California Instruction Permit (under age 18), you must:
- Be at least 15 ½ but under 18.
- Have a Certificate of Completion/Enrollment of Driver Education.
- Complete the California Driver’s License or ID Card Application.
- Have a parent(s)/guardian(s) sign the application.
- Visit a DMV office (schedule an appointment), where you will:
 - Bring your California Identification Card or proof of identity and residency. (Federal Noncompliant/REAL ID/AB60)
 - Pay the application fee.
 - Pass a vision exam.
 - Take a photo.
 - Take the knowledge test(s). There are multiple choice questions based on the California Driver’s Handbook, and a passing score is 80%.
Please refer to Provisional Licensing for additional information.
